Form is like an echo, like a reflection, like a light and shadow, like a mirage, like an illusion, like a flower in the sky, like a city of fragrance-eaters, like a transformation. Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are unbound and unliberated, like an echo and so forth up to like a transformation.
Why is it so?

Because all form and so forth up to consciousness are nonexistent, therefore they are unbound and unliberated. Because they are detached, therefore they are unbound and unliberated. Because they are tranquil, therefore they are unbound and unliberated. Because they are unborn, therefore they are unbound and unliberated. Because they are unceasing, therefore they are unbound and unliberated. Because they are undefiled, therefore they are unbound and unliberated. Because they are unpurified, therefore they are unbound and unliberated.
Furthermore, PunyaraÅ›mi,
Past form is unbound and unliberated, past feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are unbound and unliberated;
Future and present form are unbound and unliberated, future and present feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are unbound and unliberated.
Why is it so?

In this way, all forms up to consciousness are unbound and liberated because they are non-existent, unbound and liberated because they are detached, unbound and liberated because they are tranquil, unbound and liberated because they are unborn, unbound and liberated because they are unceasing, unbound and liberated because they are unstained, and unbound and liberated because they are unpurified.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!

Virtuous forms are unbound and liberated, and virtuous feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness are unbound and liberated. Non-virtuous and indeterminate forms are unbound and liberated;
non-virtuous and indeterminate feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness are unbound and liberated.
Why is it so?

In this way, all forms up to consciousness are unbound and liberated because they are non-existent, unbound and liberated because they are detached, unbound and liberated because they are tranquil, unbound and liberated because they are unborn, unbound and liberated because they are unceasing, unbound and liberated because they are unstained, and unbound and liberated because they are unpurified.
Moreover, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!
Worldly form is neither bound nor liberated, worldly feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither bound nor liberated;
Supramundane form is neither bound nor liberated, supramundane feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither bound nor liberated.
Why is it so?

Because all form up to consciousness are non-existent, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated, because they are detached, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated, because they are tranquil, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated, because they are unborn, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated, because they are unceasing, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated, because they are unstained, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated, because they are pure, therefore they are neither bound nor liberated.
Moreover, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!
Contaminated form is neither bound nor liberated, contaminated feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither bound nor liberated;
Uncontaminated form is neither bound nor liberated, uncontaminated feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are neither bound nor liberated.
Why is it so?

In the same way, all forms up to consciousness are unfettered and liberated because they are non-existent, unfettered and liberated because they are detached, unfettered and liberated because they are tranquil, unfettered and liberated because they are unborn, unfettered and liberated because they are unceasing, unfettered and liberated because they are unstained, and unfettered and liberated because they are unpurified.
Furthermore, PunyaraÅ›mi,
all dharmas are unfettered and liberated.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas are non-existent, detached, tranquil, unborn, unceasing, unstained, and unpurified, they are unfettered and liberated.
Furthermore, PunyaraÅ›mi,
the perfection of generosity is unfettered and liberated, and the perfections of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom are unfettered and liberated.
Why is it so?
Because the perfections such as giving are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are neither bound nor liberated.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra,

The emptiness of internal phenomena is neither bound nor liberated, the emptiness of external phenomena, the emptiness of both external and internal phenomena, the emptiness of emptiness, the great emptiness, the emptiness of ultimate reality, the emptiness of conditioned phenomena, the emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, the emptiness of the unlimited, the emptiness of that which has neither beginning nor end, the emptiness of non-dispersal, the emptiness of inherent existence, the emptiness of specific and general characteristics, the emptiness of all phenomena, the emptiness of non-apprehension, the emptiness of essential nature, the emptiness of essential nature of non-existence, and the emptiness of the essential nature of non-existence of essential nature are neither bound nor liberated.
Why is it so?

Because the emptiness of internal phenomena and so forth are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are neither bound nor liberated.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra,

The four establishments of mindfulness are unfettered and unliberated, and the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of awakening, and eightfold noble path are unfettered and unliberated.
Why is it so?
Because the four establishments of mindfulness and so forth are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are pure, and are unfettered and unliberated.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra,

in the same way, the TathÄgata's ten powers are unfettered and unliberated, and the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed discernments, great loving-kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha are unfettered and unliberated.
Why is it so?
Because the ten powers and so forth are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are pure, and are unfettered and unliberated.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra,
The practices of all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are without bondage and without liberation, and the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment of the buddhas is without bondage and without liberation.
Why is it so?

Because the practices of bodhisattvas and so forth are nonexistent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are without bondage and without liberation.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!
The knowledge of all modes is without bondage and without liberation, and the knowledge of path aspects and the knowledge of all aspects are without bondage and without liberation.
Why is it so?

Because the knowledge of all modes and so forth are nonexistent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are without bondage and without liberation.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!

Suchness is without bondage and without liberation, and the dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, birthlessness nature, dharma determination, dharma abiding, and ultimate reality are without bondage and without liberation.
Why is it so?
Because suchness and so forth are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are neither bound nor liberated.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are neither bound nor liberated, and TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones are neither bound nor liberated.
Why is it so?

Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas and tathÄgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened ones are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are neither bound nor liberated.
Furthermore, PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!
All conditioned [phenomena] are neither bound nor liberated, and all unconditioned [phenomena] are neither bound nor liberated.
Why is it so?
Because conditioned [phenomena] and so forth are non-existent, are far removed, are tranquil, are unborn, are unceasing, are unstained, are unpurified, and are neither bound nor liberated.
PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should use non-apprehension as a skillful means to truly understand this subtle Dharma door of no bondage and no liberation.
PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should use non-apprehension as a skillful means to diligently cultivate the perfections of giving, morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom, up to the four establishments of mindfulness, up to the knowledge of all modes.
PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should use non-apprehension as a skillful means to abide in the perfections of giving, morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom, up to the four establishments of mindfulness, up to the knowledge of all modes, which are without bondage and without liberation.
PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, using non-apprehension as a skillful means, should bring to maturity sentient beings who are neither bound nor liberated, should adorn and purify buddha-lands that are neither bound nor liberated, should attend and make offerings to buddhas who are neither bound nor liberated, and should listen to and accept the Dharma that is neither bound nor liberated.
PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra!

Chapter on SamÄdhi, Part 2, Chapter 16, Part 1 on SamÄdhi At that time, SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What are the characteristics of the Great Vehicle of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
How should one know that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have set out in the Great Vehicle?
From where does this Great Vehicle emerge?
To where does it go and abide?
What does this Great Vehicle rely on?
Who rides in this Great Vehicle and emerges?
The Buddha told SubhÅ«ti:
The first question you asked, 'What are the characteristics of the Great Vehicle of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?'
SubhÅ«ti!
The six perfections are the characteristics of the Great Vehicle of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
What are the six?
They are the perfection of giving, the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of meditation, and the perfection of wisdom.
SubhÅ«ti!
What is the perfection of giving?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind that is in accord with omniscience, with great compassion at the forefront, using non-apprehension as the skillful means, give away all their internal and external possessions, and also encourage others to give away their internal and external possessions, and together with all sentient beings dedicate these wholesome roots towards omniscience,
SubhÅ«ti!
This is the perfection of giving of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
SubhÅ«ti!
What is the perfection of morality?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind unified with the cognition of the all-knowing, with great compassion at the forefront, using non-apprehension as the skillful means, themselves uphold the ten wholesome courses of action, and also encourage others to uphold the ten wholesome courses of action, and with these wholesome roots together dedicate them to the cognition of the all-knowing.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is the perfection of morality of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
SubhÅ«ti!
What is the perfection of patience?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind unified with the cognition of the all-knowing, with great compassion at the forefront, using non-apprehension as the skillful means, themselves possess supreme patience, and also encourage others to possess supreme patience, and with these wholesome roots together dedicate them to the cognition of the all-knowing.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is the perfection of patience of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
SubhÅ«ti!
What is the perfection of vigor?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind unified with the cognition of all aspects, with great compassion at the forefront, using non-apprehension as a skillful means, themselves diligently cultivate the five perfections and do not abandon them, and also encourage others to diligently cultivate the five perfections and not abandon them, and take this wholesome root and together with all sentient beings dedicate it towards omniscience.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is the perfection of vigor for bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
SubhÅ«ti!
What is the perfection of meditation?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind associated with omniscience, with great compassion at the forefront, using non-apprehension as skillful means, skillfully enter the meditative absorptions, immeasurable [attitudes], and formless [absorptions] on their own, they will never take birth under the influence of those [attainments]. They are also able to encourage others to skillfully enter the meditative absorptions, immeasurable [attitudes], and formless [absorptions], not taking birth under the influence of those meditative concentrations. They share this wholesome root with all sentient beings, dedicating it together to omniscience.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is the perfection of meditative absorption for bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
SubhÅ«ti!
What is the perfection of wisdom?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with a mind that is in accord with omniscience, with great compassion at the forefront, using non-apprehension as skillful means, themselves contemplate the nature of all dharmas as it truly is, without grasping or attachment to the nature of dharmas, and also encourage others to contemplate the nature of all dharmas as it truly is, without grasping or attachment to the nature of dharmas, and dedicate this wholesome root together with all sentient beings towards omniscience.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
SubhÅ«ti should know!
This is the characteristic of the Great Vehicle of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!

The characteristics of the Great Vehicle of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are as follows: inner emptiness, outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of the conditioned, emptiness of the unconditioned, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion and non-dispersion, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of general and specific characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of intrinsic nature, and emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence.
What is inner emptiness?
Inner means inner dharmas, namely the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
One should know that here, the eyes are empty of the eyes, not permanent and not perishable, up to the mind is empty of the mind, not permanent and not perishable.
Why is it so?
Because the inherent nature is like that.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called inner emptiness.
What is outer emptiness?
Outer means outer dharmas, namely form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
One should know that in this case form is empty of form, neither ceasing nor eternal, up to phenomena are empty of phenomena, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is thus.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called external emptiness.
What is internal and external emptiness?
Internal and external refers to internal and external dharmas, namely the six sense bases within and the six sense bases without.
One should know that in this case internal dharmas are empty of external dharmas, neither ceasing nor eternal, and external dharmas are empty of internal dharmas, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is thus.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called internal and external emptiness.
What is emptiness of emptiness?
Emptiness refers to the emptiness of all dharmas, and this emptiness is again empty of emptiness, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is thus.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called emptiness of emptiness.
What is great emptiness?
Great refers to the ten directions, namely east, west, north, south, the four intermediate directions, and above and below.
One should know that in this context, the east is empty of the east, not permanent, not perishable, up to the nadir is empty of the nadir, not permanent, not perishable.
Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called great emptiness.
What is the emptiness of ultimate reality?
Ultimate reality refers to nirvÄá¹‡a.
One should know that in this context, nirvÄá¹‡a is empty of nirvÄá¹‡a, not permanent, not perishable.
Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of ultimate reality.
What is the emptiness of the conditioned?
The conditioned refers to the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm.

One should know that in this context, the desire realm is empty of the desire realm, not permanent, not perishable, the form and formless realms are empty of the form and formless realms, not permanent, not perishable.
Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature.
SubhÅ«ti!ğŸ”½This is called the emptiness of the conditioned.
What is the emptiness of the unconditioned?
The unconditioned refers to that which is unborn, unceasing, neither defiled nor undefiled, and neither to be increased nor decreased.
One should know that here the unconditioned is due to the emptiness of the unconditioned, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because its intrinsic nature is such.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of the unconditioned.
What is the emptiness of the ultimate?
The ultimate refers to that which is ultimately unobtainable.
One should know that here the ultimate is due to the emptiness of the ultimate, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because its intrinsic nature is such.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of the ultimate.
What is the emptiness of the beginningless and endless?
The beginningless and endless refer to that which has no beginning or end that can be obtained.
One should know that here the beginningless and endless is due to the emptiness of the beginningless and endless, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because its intrinsic nature is such.
SubhÅ«ti!ğŸ”½This is called the emptiness of the beginningless and endless.
What is the emptiness of non-dispersal?
Scattered means that there is letting go, discarding, and abandoning, while not scattered means that there is no letting go, discarding, or abandoning.
One should know that in this context, scattered and not scattered are due to the emptiness of scattered and not scattered, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is like that.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of scattered and not scattered.
What is the emptiness of intrinsic nature?

Intrinsic nature refers to the nature of conditioned phenomena and the nature of unconditioned phenomena. All of these are not created by Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, or tathÄgatas, nor are they created by others. Therefore, it is called the intrinsic nature.
One should know that in this context, the intrinsic nature is due to the emptiness of intrinsic nature, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is like that.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of intrinsic nature.
What is the emptiness of self and common characteristics?

The specific characteristics refer to the specific characteristics of all dharmas, such as the specific characteristic of form being to transform and obstruct, the specific characteristic of feeling being to experience, the specific characteristic of perception being to grasp characteristics, the specific characteristic of mental formations being to form, and the specific characteristic of consciousness being to cognize. Such specific characteristics of conditioned dharmas and the specific characteristics of unconditioned dharmas are the specific characteristics.

The common characteristics refer to the common characteristics of all dharmas, such as the common characteristic of suffering being the characteristic of contaminated dharmas, the common characteristic of impermanence being the characteristic of conditioned dharmas, and the common characteristic of emptiness and non-self being the characteristic of all dharmas. There are innumerable such common characteristics.
One should know that in this context, the specific and common characteristics are empty of their own specific and common characteristics, are neither eternal nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because it is their inherent nature.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of specific and common characteristics.
What is the emptiness of all dharmas?

All dharmas refer to the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, and eighteen elements, with form and without form, visible and invisible, resistant and unresistant, contaminated and uncontaminated, conditioned and unconditioned, these are all dharmas.
One should know that in this regard, all dharmas are empty of all dharmas, neither ceasing nor being destroyed.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is thus.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of all dharmas.
What is the emptiness of non-apprehension?
Non-apprehension refers to the non-apprehension of all dharmas that are sought in this regard.
One should know that in this regard, non-apprehension is empty of non-apprehension, neither ceasing nor being destroyed.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is thus.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of non-apprehension.
What is the emptiness of intrinsic nature?
Intrinsic nature refers to the non-apprehension of the slightest intrinsic nature in this regard.
One should know that in this regard, the absence of intrinsic nature is empty of the absence of intrinsic nature, neither ceasing nor being destroyed.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature is thus.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of nature.
What is the emptiness of self-nature?
Self-nature refers to the ability of dharmas to combine and form their own nature.
It should be known that in this case, self-nature is empty of self-nature, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is this?
Because the fundamental nature is so.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of self-nature.
What is the emptiness of the nature of non-existence?
The nature of non-existence refers to the nature of dharmas that cannot combine and form their own nature.
It should be known that in this case, the nature of non-existence is empty of the nature of non-existence, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is this?
Because the fundamental nature is so.
SubhÅ«ti!
This is called the emptiness of the nature of non-existence.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
Existence is empty of existence, non-existence is empty of non-existence, self-nature is empty of self-nature, and other-nature is empty of other-nature.
What is existence empty of existence?
Existence refers to conditioned dharmas, and this existence is empty due to the emptiness of existence.
How is non-existence empty due to the emptiness of non-existence?
Non-existence refers to unconditioned dharmas, and this non-existence is empty due to the emptiness of non-existence.
How is self-nature empty due to self-nature?

It means that all dharmas are empty of self-nature. This emptiness is not created by cognition, not created by views, and not created by anything else. This is called self-nature being empty due to self-nature.
How is other-nature empty due to other-nature?

It means that all dharmas, whether a Buddha appears in the world or not, abide by the Dharma, are determined by the Dharma, have the nature of the Dharma realm, have the nature of equality of the Dharma, have the nature of detachment from birth of the Dharma, have suchness, have non-false nature, have unchanging nature, and have the ultimate reality, all due to other-nature, are empty. This is called other-nature being empty due to other-nature.
SubhÅ«ti should know!
This is the characteristic of the Great Vehicle of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.

Chapter on Cultivating the Ground, Part 2, Chapter 18, Part 1 on Cultivating the Ground Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
You asked, 'By what standard should one know that a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has set out in the Great Vehicle?'

Third, using non-attainment as a skillful means, they cultivate the practice of giving, because the giver, the recipient, and the gift are unobtainable.
Fourth, using non-attainment as a skillful means, they cultivate the practice of associating with good friends, because they are not attached to any good friends.
Fifth, using non-attainment as a skillful means, they cultivate the practice of seeking the Dharma, because the Dharma that is sought is unobtainable.
Sixth, using non-attainment as a skillful means, they cultivate the practice of always delighting in leaving the home life, because the home life that is abandoned is unobtainable.

You asked, 'From where does this Great Vehicle emerge, and where does it abide?'
SubhÅ«ti!
Thus, this Great Vehicle goes forth from the three realms and abides in the cognition of all modes, yet it has no going forth and no abiding, because it takes non-duality as its means.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!

Whether it is the Great Vehicle or the cognition of all modes, these two dharmas are neither conjoined nor disjoined, are formless, invisible, non-resistant, and of one mark, which is to say, the mark of the absence of marks.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
The dharma of the absence of marks does not go forth in the past, does not go forth in the future, and does not go forth in the present.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!

Those who wish to cause the dharma of the absence of marks to go forth are then causing the empty dharmadhÄtu to go forth, yet the empty dharmadhÄtu cannot go forth from the three realms, and also cannot abide in the cognition of all modes.

Because the empty dharmadhÄtu is empty of the intrinsic nature of the empty dharmadhÄtu.
SubhÅ«ti!

Those who wish to make the dharma of signlessness have emergence and abiding would then wish to make suchness, emptiness, the realm of reality, the inconceivable realm, the realm of peace, the realm of cessation, the realm of separation, and the realm of nirvana also have emergence and abiding. Because the emptiness of form is empty of the intrinsic nature of the emptiness of form.
